powerwalk.tasks

Class Task

  • java.lang.Object
    • powerwalk.tasks.Task
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Comparable<Task>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ReturnTask, StepTask

    public abstract class Task
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Comparable<Task>
    Task Class that is used to queue tasks for the Bot to execute.

    Every Task has a priority and a name. The priority is used by the Bot class to sort the Tasks by priority, and execute the Task with the highest priority first. The default priority is 0. After the Task is created, the priority cannot be changed anymore.

    The name is used in log messages and can also be used for identification. If an invalid name is set (either null or an empty String), the old name is kept. When no valid name has been set, the name of the Task is "Generic Task".

    • Method Detail

      • execute

        public abstract void execute()
        The method that is run by the Bot when this task is scheduled.

        Classes that override this method must make sure that this method does not throw any Exceptions, for they will not be caught.

      • getPriority

        public int getPriority()
        Returns the priority of this Task
        Returns:
        the priority of this Task

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(Task t)
        Returns the difference in Priority between this Task and Task t
        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<Task>
        Parameters:
        t - The Task to compare this Task to
        Returns:
        a negative number when this Task has a lower Priority, a positive number when this Task has a higher Priority, and zero when the Priorities are equal.

      • cancel

        public void cancel()
        Cancels this Task as quickly as possible.

        By default this method does nothing. Subclasses of this class should override this method when the action is taking quite some time to complete.

        This method should return without throwing exceptions and calling cancel on a running task should not cause exceptions to occur in the execute method.

      • setName

        public void setName(java.lang.String name)
        Sets a name for this Task. The name can be used for identification and can be found back in logs. If the given name is either null or the empty String, this method does nothing.
        Parameters:
        name - the new name for this Task

      • getName

        public java.lang.String getName()
        returns the assigned name for this Task. When no name has been assigned, this method returns "Generic Task".
        Returns:
        the name of this Task

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Resets this Task, allowing it to be run again.

        By default, this method throws an UnsupportedOperationException. Classes that do not override this method are considered to be able to run only once.

        If a subclass of Task overrides this method, and does not throw an UnsupportedOperationException, the Bot assumes the Task is reset and ready to be run again when this method returns.

        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - when this Task is not resettable

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object other)
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object

      • sleep

        public static void sleep(int min,
         int max)
        This method waits a pseudo-random time between min and max milliseconds, and then returns.

        This method is effectively the same as calling org.powerbot.core.script.job.Task.sleep(min,max);

        This method should actually not belong in Task, but seeing as many people like to use the Task.sleep() methods, they were implemented here to allow for easy access even when having imports for PowerWalk's Task class.

        Parameters:
        min - the minimum waiting time.
        max - the maximum waiting time.

      • sleep

        public static void sleep(int time)
        This method waits a time milliseconds, and then returns.

        This method is effectively the same as calling org.powerbot.core.script.job.Task.sleep(time);

        This method should actually not belong in Task, but seeing as many people like to use the Task.sleep() methods, they were implemented here to allow for easy access even when having imports for PowerWalk's Task class.

        Parameters:
        time - the waiting time
